text:
You have to give anything this fast, healthy and so full of flavor a 5.  Note this isn't a recipe for small children or others with a tongue that can't handle heat.  I'd cut back on the red pepper quite a bit if you want to achieve that.  For me, however, the recipes worked perfectly as is.  As others suggested I doubled the ingredients for the sauce and it's worth noting that this great sauce can be made well in advance, heck, keeping some in the fridge handy for those days you just don't fee like cooking.

text:
This was by far the best stir fry-ish recipe I have ever made at home. I would suggest it to anyone! The ginger is a must, and keep the same amount of red pepper, because the spiciness is perfect! Just one note: if you decide to add frozen/fresh veggies (we did), be sure to double or even triple the liquid ingredients (we tripled them and it was perfect) like someone earlier suggested.

None
text:
This recipe had a similar taste to General Tsao's Chicken found on this site but was much healthier!  The recipe is good as is!
I have however,  made it numerous times and have adjusted a few things to my liking.  I like to double the sauce, decrease the hot peppers and only use 1 teaspoon of oil.  I also have found that using uncooked, peeled and deveined shrimp gives the dish a much better taste.  I just cook it in the oil until opaque before adding the sauce.  I just tried adding pea pods at the end, just until heated through, which was a great asian compliment to the meal.  We always serve it over botan rice.  A wonderful low fat, low calorie meal!

text:
I give this 4 and a half stars, but only because I didn't think up this recipe first!  It tastes very much like what you would get at the restaurant.  I made it twice, both were very good. I added one bag of stir fry veggies, the frozen kind, just prepare in the microwave and drain well before adding to the finished shrimp mixture. Could use fresh veggies as well, but I like the frozen. I also tried crushing 2 of the cloves of garlic and adding them to the sauce and using the remaining 2 cloves as recipe says, it gives the sauce a more garlic flavor.Also be careful not to overcook the shrimp!

text:
AMAZING! This recipe is a perfect mixture of tangy not-to-sweet sauce and a little bite of spicy-ness. It really only took 20 minutes (what I thought was amazing!). One suggestion though, if you are making this recipe use 6 tablespoons of water (not 4) and use more olive oil when cooking. Also, don't let the smell of the sauce confuse you at first, I thought it was disguisting too. But, when you cook it the sauce gets REALLY yummy! This recipe was amazing and I deffintaly recomend this!

text:
I have a very similar recipe to this one.  It calls for 1 lb shrimp, fresh ginger, garlic, Tbsp rice wine & I add one can chopped stewed tomatoes.  It doesn't really need the honey because the stewed tomatoes give it sweetness.  Served with rice this recipe with these additions makes it 5 stars & a wonderful meal for family or guests.  You won't have any leftovers !

text:
This was very good.  I did do this a little differently for fear of the shrimp getting too rubbery from being over cooked.  Cooked the shrimp first then added the green onions and garlic to cook....then the sauce.  Let it bubble away for about 10 minutes and added the shrimp back for a minute or so just to reheat.  Also added fresh ginger instead of ground and just a little brown sugar to the sauce.  Delicious, thanks for the post.

country:

text:
OMG! This was SO good! I am 100% pleasantly surprised. Another bonus? My hubby's favorite style of Chinese cooking is Szechwan! I like shrimp, but most often when I marinate or add sauce to them, I am left with BLAND shrimp (i.e. the shrimp don't soak up any of the marinade / sauce). That certainly wasn't the case here! This sauce is sooooo flavorful and it coats the shrimp nicely. As many others suggested, I too doubled the sauce, but in retrospect, don't think that was necessary. I had MORE than enough sauce to cover my 1 lb. bag of shrimp (not wanting to waste the remaining 1/4 lb., I used the entire bag). I do, however, think it's imperative to double or even triple the sauce if you plan to add veggies (they will soak up a LOT of sauce). And, on that note.... Although unappealing at first (the sauce smells horrid when initially mixed), the sauce ends up being the star here. :) Oh, and uncooked shrimp are NOT necessary. It literally took just a couple minutes for my sauce to thicken, barely enough time to turn my shrimp  to "rubber." Serving over brown rice with a side of steamed broccoli (to appease my broccoli hating hubby, I didn't add it to the entree) made this OUTSTANDING. Fortune cookies and iced green tea completed our meal. Thanks for sharing, FOODGU1! :-)

Display Name:
GUYCHEF

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very easy dish to make at the last minute. I have made this a half dozen times and most of the time it’s a last minute decision. You DO NOT have to spend big bucks on the shrimp to make this dish. I always keep a bag of “Sam’s Club” cooked shrimp in the freezer for a quick meal and it works great for this recipe.  The shrimp are run under cold water for 5-10 minutes to thaw, then peeled and ready for the pan.  I recommend you quadruple the sauce! The ingredients are cheap, the sauce is great and since my recommendation is to since this over penne pasta, (or rice) more sauce is needed. In my view, the recipe recommendation quantity of crushed red pepper results in a “medium to mild” on my hot taste scale. I have doubled the pepper which results in a “hot” rating and also have cut it in half for very mild when serving this to young children. Be sure to decide where you want this to be on the “hot taste scale” before you add the pepper. It’s a great recipe but if you don’t measure carefully, you can easily make this too hot for some palates.
Review:

userID:
3539186
Display Name:
Nicole

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG, best shrimps ever!  Solid reicpe, easy and quick, and out of the world tasty!!  Here are some tips from a Chinese girl if you want even more authentic flavor:

-Use 1.5-2 lbs raw shrimp(you can buy the peeled frozen shrimps with tail on)!  This alone will kick this dish up a couple notches since the raw ones get more shrimp flavor in.
-Use fresh ginger!
-Triple the sauce, leave out the starch till the end (only use 1 TBS of corn starch, dilute in about 2 TBS water), I also added about 1 TBS of rice vinegar,  the sauce was sooooooooooo yummy to eat with rice.

Here is how I made it with the above changes.  Heat up about 2-3 TBS of grapeseed oil(shrimps are very low cal, so don't feel bad for adding some oil here), cut up about at least 1 thumb size of fresh ginger(first cut into match sticks, then cut into tiny bits), cut up 1-2 small bunch of green onions(white and light green part only).  Fry them up till fragrant, toss in the thawed and drained shrimps, fry for 1-2 minutes over high heat, then pour in the tripled sauce, boil for 1-2 minutes, add the starch solution, stir. Add salt. Done!

Best ever shrimps hands down!!! gotta try it.

This is awesome!  We're not Chinese food eaters, so I can't compare to the restaurant version, but this is awesome!  I doubled the sauce and left out the ginger (I knew that would make it too *Asian* for Mr. LTH).  I also added more garlic than called for. This is so simple, so quick, and so yummy it will def become a regular at the LTH house...I'm already looking forward to the leftovers for lunch tomorrow!!!!  BTW-this made enough for dinner for both of us and 1 leftover portion for lunch tomorrow.  TY for a great recipe!

text:
This is by far the best stir fry I have ever made and it is now my go-to recipe. I made some adjustments based on my pantry: I used raw shrimp, I shaved fresh ginger (I keep one in the freezer at all times), and I replaced the red chili flakes with a little squirt of siracha sauce because I don't like really spicy food and it gave me the right heat.  My husband cleaned his plate and we discussed how awesome this would be as a beef marinade for the grill.

OH MY GOODNESS, this was fabulous!  Never thought I could make chinese food like PF Changs, but with this recipe it was possible!  The flavor was perfect.  Added steamed brocolli & carrots. Doubling would be PLENTY.  TRY THIS RECIPE!

None
country:
None
text:
The reason I'm giving this only 3 stars is because the ingredient amounts need to be adjusted. The ketchup was really overpowering and dominated the flavor of the dish; 2 teaspoons of honey was a tad too sweet; it wasn't nearly spicy enough to be called szechwan and surprisingly, seemed to need even more red pepper than half a teaspoon AND the amount of cornstarch was WAY off. I'd say to cut it back by half if you don't want your sauce to turn to paste. I think the idea of this recipe has potential, but far too much "tweaking" would be required to get there from here. You'd have to just about re-write the entire recipe to make it come out good.

text:
Great!  I made a few changes though. I doubled the sauce like everyone else suggested, only I put it a little less ketchup and a little more soy sauce. I also used Low Sodium soy sauce instead of the regular stuff.  I also added about 1/4 teaspoon of Honey to kick up the sweetness. It ended up being a perfect balance between sweet and spicy.  I tossed in some Broc/Corn/Red Pep veggie mix for color and texture, and I served it over some instant Asian Rice.  The wife really liked it as well, so we will definitely make this again. Remember to ease up on the ketchup a little bit if you are worried about the ketchup taste coming out too much.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a lovely dish. So quick and so easy. I didn't change anything except doubling the sauce. The beauty of this recipe is that it's so quick and easy and uses simple ingredients you can have on hand any time. Fresh shrimp? Yes, perhaps it would make it better, but, it would also add, not only to cooking time, but to availability of ingredients. Frozen is already in your freezer, fresh needs a trip to the store AND needs to be peeled and deveined. Some people prefer fresh ginger, some, me included, prefer the powdered. As for the hot pepper flakes.... the amount you use depends completely on the pepper flakes you have. I've had some that had almost no heat, then again some that burned the enamel off my teeth. KNOW YOUR PEPPER! And taste the sauce before you add it. Add more if you need it. The basic recipe is what I gave 5 stars for. I can add anything I want to that, and it won't change my rating. Thank you for a great recipe. I'm going to try it with some cooked, frozen turkey meat I have in the freezer. I have no doubt it will be fabulous.

text:
I followed this recipe almost exactly...with a few little changes.  I used fresh grated ginger instead of ground, and I also added some fresh sliced carrots and broccoli to the mix.  A little tip: saute the veg in a little olive oil to soften them up before you throw them with the shrimp or else the shrimp will get all rubbery.  Because I added veg, I doubled the sauce recipe which I found was sufficient.  i dont like things too saucy. Also, I found this a little spicy for my taste so if you're like me...you might want to ease back a bit on the chili/ginger.  I will DEFINITELY make this again. :)

This was exceptional. The recipe as is, is perfect. But since I'm a saucy person, I tripled the ingredients for this sauce.  I also did this due to the fact that I had added broccoli, zucchini, onion, and celery. One reviewer suggested cutting back on the red chili flakes if anyone eating this doesn't like hot. I agree. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tripled everything so as to add a bag of frozen mixed stir-fry veggies to a lb or so of medium frozen pre-cooked shrimp. Used:  chili sauce instead of ketchup since I had it; about 2 tsp grated frozen ginger; sesame seed oil; and a whole head of garlic (12 cloves.) Would've done the fresh chopped broccoli and slivered carrots instead of frozen vegs, but am making broccoli-cheese soup later this week. Made this a day ahead and just put it all in a glass jar, (oil, uncooked garlic and onions too) shook it well and fridged it. To finish, heated sauce with veggies till thickened, then added thawed shrimp just till heated through. Served over jasmati rice cooked in chicken broth instead of water. 5 stars = good enough to pass on to the daughter!  :)

text:
This recipe won't change my life, but was good. Didn't have honey so used brown sugar and my green onions had gone bad (thank you walmart) after 2 days so I did without. I quadrupled everything but only tripled the ketchup and ginger. Still a little bit ketchup-y, but not bad for how cheap and easy this is. I only doubled the crushed red pepper because we don't like too much heat. I made this recipe for two. Added peppers and zucchini over white rice and there was quite a bit of sauce left over (with a lot of liquid on the plate). I will make this again, with maybe a few tweaks.

This was very good.  I took the advice of a few others, and I tripled the liquid/sauce mix.  I'm glad I did, because it was necessary (this was the only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5).   I also added a small amount of broccoli florets, baby carrots, and tofu just to give it a little more variety and color.  The amount of red pepper flakes that the recipe called for is the perfect amount.  I wouldn't change that a bit.  It had just enough kick to be spicy, but not too much to be overwhelming.  I will definitely make this again. :)

This was good - and the only reason I gave it four stars was because I tripled the sauce recipe and it was so spicy!  I was sweating - but I loved it.  My husband loved it and said 'Now this is GOOD!"  So - if you triple the sauce...maybe don't triple the crushed red pepper.  I will definitely make this again. **Second Review - I made this again and it was so good.  I tripled the sauce recipe and there was a ton of thick bubbly sauce. I served it over rice and I wish I had made more rice to help sop up the sauce.  Nice and spicy - not as bad as last time though because I only doubled the crushed red pepper.  :)

I liked this very much. It didn't look or taste very promising just going by the made up sauce ingredients. The garlic and onion really rounded out the flavour. Be sure to double the sauce. I did not completely double the red pepper flakes-used a scant 3/4 tsp-. The spice level was tastable but not burning. My 12yr. old son had chosen to have spagetti instead of this for his dinner but I found him over the fry pan with a fork, eating the shrimp with a grin on his face. This was extreemly fast to put together. I served over rice, squeezed with a little lime juice and sprinkled  very lightly with salt. Thank so much.

text:
I give this recipe a 5 after tweaking it a little after reading the reviews. I tripled the sauce (we like sauce), cut the ketchup down to 1 Tbsp. plus a little extra squeeze, added an extra 1/2 tsp. soy sauce and a splash of terriyaki plus fresh garlic about 1 clove(let sauce marinade overnight) and some par-boiled asparagus. My husband loved it. We've been married for 10 years and my husband (a gourmet chef) didn't know I could cook until last week I started looking up healthy recipes, since i am on a diet. We're on our second honeymoon!

text:
One review I read said if your tongue can't handle the heat, reduce the red pepper.  I'm not big on spicy; however, my husband is.  I tried the recipe exactly just to see how much I could handle.  I poured myself a glass of milk to assist if needed.  It was spicy, but it was manageable for me.  I took a sip of milk every 2 or 3 bites to reduce the fire on my tongue.  I thought it tasted fantastic, although it could have used a little salt.  Next time I make it, I will reduce the pepper to 1/4 tsp and add a dash of salt.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Used chili sauce instead of ketchup.  Increased water by 2 TBLS.  Used fresh grated ginger.  Wish I had fresh garlic but didn't so used jared instead. Doubled sauce.  Used a medium chopped onion as well as 5 chopped green onions. Cooked onion & garlic in sesame oil 1st then added the sauce mixture to pan and let it thicken-about 8-10 minutes.  Finally, added pre-frozen, thawed shrimp & cooked, shelled edemame.  Cooked until heated through.  Served on top of angel hair pasta.  Broccoli slaw as a side dish.  Yum!

None
text:
This is my go to recipe for Chinese at home!  In fact, it is better than any takeout!  I double the sauce and add my favorite vegetables, all of which I cook separately (broccoli, peppers, onion, water chestnuts, mushrooms, etc.).  This really is best with raw shrimp.  I cook all the vegetables first and remove them, cover to keep warm, and set aside.  Then I cook as directed and add the vegetables and sauce when the shrimp is "just done" and cooks as directed until thickened.  I serve with rice.  So delicious!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent dish. Even though I doubled the amount of sauce it was still not enough because I also added broccoli and carrots, so if you want to add veggies, make sure you make enough sauce. I also used raw shrimp and cooked it in the oil with the garlic and onion to give it more flavor and used Sambal instead of the crushed red pepper. One last thing, either cut the cornstarch in half or add more water, it's up to you. If you leave it as is, it is extremely thick. Thanks for the recipe, it was delicious!

text:
For us, the recipe worked well as written although we used raw wild shrimp. We thought it was mildly spicy but not a ‘hot’ dish (might add a little cayenne pepper next time as one reviewer suggested). It does not taste Szechwan like one typically encounters in a Chinese restaurant but the flavor was still quite good. I agree with many other reviewers about increasing the quantity of sauce. I went with those suggesting tripling the sauce thinking that a bit of extra unused sauce is no big deal. This amount turned out about right for us. The shrimp were served over a bed of white Basmati rice.  Thank you FOODGU1 for sharing this recipe.

text:
SO where do I begin? This dish was rather quick to make first off = 1 star maybe 2. I tripled the recipe and got a sauce that was a little thin or soupy consistency. That can also be in part to i only put in about 1/2 tsp of cornstarch and about 3 TBSP of ketchup (to omit the kethchupy taste many other reviews refer to). The final product wasn't bad but it wasn't THAT impressive. This is a good base recipe to build a pond. I used fresh ginger and i assed many different types of veggies for ex. broccoli, bell peppers(red and yellow)...I cooked jasmine rice and carrots in a honey glaze from another recipe that I love. In all next time I make this I will play with it a bit more. Add more seasonings or something. Oh i almost forgot- i also seasoned my RAW shrimp with some season salt and garlic salt (hence i like salt)...

text:
This was delicious, so easy, and the boyfriend loved it.  If you don't like spice, just use a pinch of the red chili peppers.  The 1/2 teaspoon is pretty spicy, but it meshes with the dish well.

No need to use cornstarch if you don't have it - just sprinkle in a 1/2 tsp of flour after pouring the sauce in the pan - just to thicken it up a little bit.

Prep time is practically nothing, and the cooking time is only 10 minutes.  Perfect, easy, fast, delicious.

Goes well over a bed of couscous and with some steamed broccoli.

text:
I hate to say this...I really do...but today's high-end sauces are so delicious, diverse, and easy that it's just a lot more time-friendly to use one instead of putting together this admittedly great recipe.  Homemade is always best, especially when you can control the ingredients and avoid preservatives.  Not to mention the usually superior taste and the satisfaction of presenting a dish you are proud of having put together yourself.  But since this isn't really all natural anyway...I say go with the best of the best jar stuff added to raw shrimp sauteed in garlic and oil.   I love cooking. But sometimes it's not the best use of my time for the relative trade-off in taste.

country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out to be a great one-pan lunch option for my other half and I. The sauce was quick to make and the ingredients were mostly things I already had on hand, making it extra affordable. We served it with a pouch of instant rice with some red peppers mixed into the sauce. Overall it had a very nice flavour and satisfied our craving for Chinese food!   That being said, the sauce does have a certain "ketchup-y" flavour (I thought it tasted similar to a chinese sweet and sour sauce), so if you're not a ketchup lover be warned! We put in about 3/4 of the recommended spice, and thought it was mild enough to use the full 1/2 tsp next time. Also used Sesame Oil instead of Vegetable, and if you have it on hand I would definitely recommend using it instead!

text:
This was really a wonderful recipe. I like to try recipes where there are not too many ingredients, or steps.I mix the "sauce" ingredients ( with  1/2  of the minced garlic added)and keep it ready in the fridge, in a small ziploc onions and garlic chopped and ready to go, and carrots and broccoli  sliced in another ziploc, as soon as the kids get home I heat oil ,throw in the onions/garlic,then the veges,then the shrimp ,then the sauce...it's all hot and bubbly ,ready to eat in 10 minutes. I have made it thrice so far, once with shrimp ,twice with chicken breasts ,(cubed,seasoned with salt/paprika ,sprinkle  cornflour and all purpose flour little to coat)....Thanks !

Very yummy recipe. I tripled the recipe and added chili paste instead of the crushed chili's and it definitely left your mouth tingly, but was perfect. Even my kids chowed down on this. I also added chunks of red and yellow bell pepper, a sweet onion and water chestnuts because they have a great texture. I added some fresh ginger in with the garlic and a splash of sesame oil. I served over jasmine rice. It was perfect and really fast. I even ate leftovers for breakfast. Nothing like nice spicy food in the morning to wake you up. I definitely recommend this recipe, its so versatile and you make it to suit your tastes.

text:
Not very authentic. I found the aroma of the dish to be a bit of a turnoff. The seafood smell comes from using "cooked shrimp." To get rid of the smell and to make it more tender, it is best to cook the shrimp through with oil first or add some cooking wine to get rid of some of the seafood smell although it doesn't work as well as oil

awesome, though i made a few changes, Instead of putting honey and water i added pineapple juice to the recipe (just about 4 Tbsp was enough, and 2 tomatos chopped up. This came out delicious. Everybody asked for more. also i didn't cook the shrimp before hand. i think that way the taste of the shrimp won't vanish. just toss it for a little bit longer before adding the sauce and then the prawns will be done with the taste still remaining. This one is a keeper

DRAGNLAW

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/10067.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely top of the line! I did not change one thing other than using fresh shrimp (all I had). So I stir cooked the fresh shrimp for just under 2 min. added the sauce and while that was bubbling and thickening the shrimp cook the rest of the way.  They were so tender! Also best to let the sauce sit for a minute or two to allow the flavours to blend. First taste, right out of the pan, they hadn't really melded yet. Ooops forgot to mention that next time I think I will use fresh ginger. To me powdered ginger is more for baking.
Another suggestion (think this has already been mentioned but..)if you use precooked shrimp, I would suggest you thicken the sauce first and then add the shrimp to heat.
This was fast, easy and super delish!
Thanks again, Foodgu1
Just wanted to say thanks again. I've now been making this for quite a few years and have not changed a thing in all this time (other than fresh shrimp & fresh ginger as noted earlier). The heat is perfect, you can taste everything exactly as you should. I serve over rice or, as in last night, rice noodles. Delish!!

text:
This is a great basic recipe for Szechuan shrimp. I mean for my family. We like things hot. I doubled the red pepper and ginger, quadrupled the garlic, and added a generous helping of Vindaloo curry. Also 2 teaspoons of apple cider vinegar. Acid brightens everything. Plus I added some lemongrass, sake, and soy sauce when I sauteed the raw shrimp (I know, not the way they outlined it, but I had raw shrimp). Unbelievable! Thank you for this great blueprint for our dinner. I did brown rice with carmelized onions, edamame, and soy sauce for an accompaniment.

I used this recipe specifically for the sauce. Rather than shrimp, I wanted to make Szechwan Chicken. Other than the meat substitution, I doubled the recipe for more sauce and doubled the red pepper flakes for our 'hot' preference. I also added fresh spinach leaves at the very end to add to our vegetable intake. With all that said, even though I made these substitutions I don't feel it really changed the overall wonderful flavor of this dish, it's all in the sauce, after all. I served over brown rice. This is a keeper with many possibilities, just maintain the integrity of the sauce. It's perfect!

Display Name:
AdirondackKid

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/806000.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you FOODGU1 - This is a keeper. I made it exactly as the recipe was written (doubled) with three exceptions: I did have uncooked shrimp available so I decided to use them, and I forgot to buy the green onions at the market today. so I had to use finely chopped Vidalia onions instead. I also had fresh ginger available, so I used that as well.

I used a pound of 16/20 count shrimp (colossal size), put the onions in the pan with oil to give them a head start, and then added the shrimp. After about 3 minutes I turned the shrimp, added the ginger and garlic, let it simmer a minute or two and then started to stir the ingredients in the pan before adding the sauce.

It didn't take long for the sauce to bubble and thicken, which was perfect because the shrimp were almost done perfectly by then. 

The flavors are awesome! Not too spicy but you get that sweet tang from the ketchup and ginger, and then the garlic and red pepper kicks in.If I had the green onions, I probably would not have put them in with the shrimp - I would have held them back with the ginger and garlic and put them all in at once. The green onions would have added color and a different texture that would probably make this dish even better. 

Great recipe!

text:
We really enjoyed this recipe. We followed it completely but used fresh shrimp. Shrimp was sauteed with the garlic and then when almost cooked through, added the sauce to finish cooking it while the sauce thickened. Please use GOOD ketchup. The cheapo Great Value ketchup will ruin this dish. If you look at other "chinese" cooking like sweet & sour sauce recipes, you will find ketchup in those recipes too, so don't let that throw you off. I have never been to the Sichuan province so I am no expert in those flavors and cannot judge the merit of the recipe name. I will try fresh ginger since I love it, but had none on hand and powdered worked just fine. I will make it again for sure!

city:

country:

text:
Hands down, this is a 5 star meal!!! You have the freedom of whipping it up with any & all of your favorite vegetables to custom design a meal that the whole family will enjoy.  I added thinly sliced carrots, snow peas, mushrooms & broccoli and used about a pound of shrimp instead of the 12 oz pkg.  I had so many veggies, that I quadrupled the sauce, and it was just perfect.  My parents and I LOVED it.  My mom even asked me to pack up a bit of the leftovers for her so she could take some to work the next day and make her coworkers jealous! My husband doesn't like shrimp, so for him, I reserved some of the veggies and the sauce beforehand, and in a separate skillet, browned some cut up chicken with the onions, garlic & oil, then threw in the veggies & sauce.  It thickened up in less than 30 seconds since it was a smaller portion.  He also gave it a 5 star review!  They all thought the spiciness was just perfect! It was just enough to get you to the point where your nose starts running a little bit, but not enough to make your tongue burn so much that you can't even enjoy the actual flavor of the food. And for those of us who like spicy food, (not flaming-my-tongue-is-swollen-&-can't-taste-anything spiciness) we all know that the "sweet spot" in spiciness is where your nose starts running but your tongue is still in tact. ;)  I tasted it with the chicken too and I loved it.  Can't wait to try it again with pork, and maybe even beef.  This recipe will definitely be gobbled up!

We all enjoyed it. I am giving this 5 stars as I cannot rate it objectionably since I was missing a key ingredient, the ginger. To rate it lower would be unfair since I did not prepare as written (I don't think ANY reviewer should rate a recipe after altering and then judging it on the outcome of their own alteration(s). It is NO longer the submitters recipe, but the reviewers.) Even so, this was a very good recipe, however a touch too hot for our liking. I needed more servings, so doubled the shrimp and thus tripled the sauce. I did cut way back, as is on the red pepper and still had plenty of heat. Also, added shrimp few minutes before serving so they would not get tough. Just needed to heat them since already cooked. Can't wait to try with the addition of the ginger!

MMMM MMMM this one is yummy. We were also serving this to our toddler so I left out the red pepper flakes and it still had a very nice sweet & sour vibe. I love how this can be made with pretty much condiments from the door of the fridge, you could make this every week and only have to buy a bag of shrimp.

country:
None
text:
Wow - that was a total hit!  I made this as stated except I doubled the sauce (a must do) and added a bit of cayenne (like 1/4 tsp) to spice it up a bit and used fresh ginger (ps - you can freeze ginger roots for a long time).  I used raw shrimp.  I cooked the raw shrimp in the garlic/onion/oil mix till just turning pink, then tossed the sauce in along with a bag of fresh stir-fry veggies and cooked for a few mins till the veggies were crunchy but not-quite-cooked.  Then I added some rice noodles in the last 3 minutes and covered to let them cook (they cook really quickly).  Tossed it all up and served.  It was DELISH and there's no more between 2 of us!  Will be making this again and again!  Thanks for sharing!

text:
I followed the recommendation of the cooks here and doubled the sauce. Unfortunately, it still wasnt enough. I think it was due to me adding all the veggies. I used a little bit less ketchup since some people here stated there was a ketchup taste. I added additional hot chilli paste, used both ground and fresh ginger, a tad more soy sauce and a little less cornstarch. For the veggies I added broccoli, mushrooms, red bell peppers and bamboo. (See the picture I uploaded). I served it over steamed white rice.

Overall, it was very tasty. My boyfriend (a picky eater) really enjoyed it. He even went for a 3rd helping! Will be making again soon.. this time I'll try it with chicken

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Busy Parent Alert:  This recipe is perfect for those days when you need a fast dinner to feed fussy kids. The flavor is fantastic and the recipe is super easy. My kid likes spicy food so he didn't mind the flavor and kick of the teaspoon of sriracha (hot chili sauce) that I used instead of red pepper flakes. The hardest part of this recipe was collecting the jars and bottles from the fridge and pantry!  I used half a bag of frozen cooked shrimp (tail on - it took a few minutes to remove these). I keep jars of ginger and minced garlic in the fridge, perfect for this recipe.  I added a bit more ginger and soy sauce and less green onion, to taste.  I also quartered lengthwise some leftover baby carrots and added some fresh sugar snap peas (they sell those steamer bags of fresh veggies in the produce section - perfect for this kind of recipe). I dragged out the rice cooker and actually made perfect rice for once - a delicious partner for this dish!  Next time, I will double the sauce (my son wanted extra) and otherwise won't change a thing.  This was a 20-30 minute meal (counting rice cooking time) that can't be beat!

text:
Honey, ketchup?! My partner was taken aback at the ingredients listed in this recipe. But don't be fooled, the end result is the perfect amount of spicy, and pretty good flavors overall.  I really like how accessible this Asian recipe is compared to others which require me to spend money on ingredients that won't get used very often in my kitchen (ex: oyster sauce).I confess I did not follow the recipe to the letter. Changes as follows: Used all the ingredients but replaced shrimp with thin slices of chicken. Fresh grated ginger instead of ground, red pepper flakes, added steamed broccoli/carrots and as others recommended doubled the sauce. Overall I am pleased with the results and will probably use this recipe again. Thanks!

text:
This is a very spicy (but tasty) dish; I suggest waiting until the very end before adding the red pepper, even if you've doubled or tripled the sauce. That way, you can add it little by little to suit your taste. Also, plan on at least doubling the sauce (if not tripling) if you serve over rice. Next time I think I'll try adding in some stir-fry veggies like broccoli and peppers!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's not as spicy as others say it is. I actually added  in some habanero peppers to make it spicier:). I'd recommend not trying to cook this in a pan - follow directions and make in a skillet or else the sauce will cook down too quickly and you'd be left with nothing but a glaze. I'd also recommend not adding habanero peppers unless you're like me and like spicy foods, or you're trying to get over a cold! Lastly, I agree with those who advise doubling up on the ingredients for the sauce. The shrimp really absorb it so you're going to need more than the recipe calls for. Enjoy - it's really a great dish!

We loved it! I made a plain batch for the kids with barely any red pepper in it, but for us I sliced up two jalapenos, with their seeds and added it to the garlic and green onions. text:
As written, I cannot say how this recipe would be. But deriving from my own experience and from the combined comments, what I came up with, using this recipe as a guideline, was definitely 5-star worthy, and very very close to what I've had when I have ordered this dish in restaurants - possibly better.   The final recipe, as I made it, is as follows:    4 tbsp ketchup  6 tbsp water  2 tbsp Sake (Rice Wine)  2 tbsp soy sauce  2 tbsp corn starch  2 tbsp honey  1/2 tsp crushed red pepper flakes  1 tsp fresh ginger (finely grated)  1/3 cup green onions  6 cloves garlic  1 lb shrimp deveined  1 tbsp sesame seeds (to finish)    Served it over rice, came out freakin' awesome. I cook a lot of Oriental flavors, Kung Pao and General Tso among them, and thanks to this recipe (albeit altered) I've now got yet another great and flavorful dish to add to my repertoire. Truly worthy of 5 stars, the way I had it.

text:
I thought this was great!  Very spicy!  I tripled the recipe as recommended by others, for 2 lbs of uncooked shrimp and 4 cups veggies.  For the cornstarch mixture I added some chili garlic sauce, fresh grated ginger, and sesame oil to deepen the flavor.  I didn't have any green onions so I added a regular sweet onion to the oil to saute, added 12 cloves minced garlic to the oil (only 1 tbsp oil, not 3), then added the veggies.  It was too dry so I added a cup of chicken stock and the shrimp too.  Once it steamed a little bit I added the sauce and let it cook more.  Served over rice and it was really yummy!  Tomorrow I'll steam another couple of cups of broccoli because there's so much sauce left over (less shrimps).

text:
This is a really great recipe, however beware the amount of crushed red pepper you use...I used the whole 1/2 tsp and it was so spicy my husband couldn't eat it. I love spicy though so I loved it, so next time I'll only use a tiny bit, pull out half of the shrimp for him and then add more to my half.  I always use Mochiko (sweet rice flour found in the Asian section of any good grocery store) in place of cornstarch in Asian recipes as it thickens wonderfully without leaving a chalky taste or weird consistency.  This is an easy, delicious, and healthy dish, you should try it!

Display Name:

city:

country:

text:
I followed previous suggestions and made a few changes... but only additions and increasing the servings:

1) Tripled the sauce recipe (Not only because I added Asian stir-fry veggies but because I always have a couple of my teens friends over for dinner and needed for than 4 servings)
2) Added a bag of frozen Asian stir-fry veggies (with water chestnuts, yum). Microwaved them separately, draining completely, and set aside.
3) I used frozen, pre-cooked shrimp, which I defrosted with cool-temp water in a bowl in the sink for about 10 minutess.
4) While shrimp, sauce and veggies were heating up in the wok, I microwaved 5-minute instant rice (6 servings)
5) When rice was done, mixed everything together (to make sure there was an even disbursement of rice, veggies and sauce.. otherwise, I'd have more or less of one or the other) and it was great

Of course, everyone commented on the spice, even though I warned them that Szechwan is meant to be spicy and this recipe was not even as spicy as in the restaurant. You can always reduce the heat by reducing the red peppers. 

They all loved the meal, though, despite the heat. My husband got the sweats (he's a big ol' baby.. but still cleaned his bowl out.

The teens all ate it. Loved it. My daughter, the anorexic (I say teasingly because she eats so little) demanded to know why I have to make such good food.. "To make you eat," I remarked back.

It was too hot for our two year old but he was happy with cheese hot dogs. 

I though the sa

text:
I tripled the recipe and turned this into a stir fry.  While I was mixing the sauce, I used raw shrimp and sauted them with garlic in a little olive oil.  Once they were almost done I added the sauce and let it simmer to thicken a bit.  While it was thickening, I microwaved two bags of "steam in bag" stirfry veggies.  When they were done I added them to the skillet and heated through.  I served over rice.  Super easy, super tasty, and a wonderful presentation.  Looked like something right out of a chinese restaurant.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2008-09-02T17:48:56.353
helpfulCount:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really delicious.  I went much heavier on the crushed red pepper for more heat.  In addition, if you plan to use more veggies than just green onion, do triple the amount of the sauce ingredients.  In peanut oil and the garlic (double the amount) I cooked the onions, thin sliced red bell pepper, cubed zucchini for about 4 minutes so they were still crunchy.  Then removed from the wok.  I added a bit more peanut oil and threw in about a pound of uncooked shrimp.  When that was part way cooked, I pushed the shrimp up the sides and added the sauce in and stirred the shrimp back in.  Then I added the veggies back in when the shrimp was just about done to coat everything in the sauce.  Just delicious.  Served over sticky rice.

None
text:
This recipe got rave reviews at home :)  However I did make a few alterations.

Alterations:

I doubled the sauce...ie...
8 tablespoons of water.
2 tablespoons of sweet chili sauce
1 tablespoon of ketchup
2 tablespoons of soy sauce
2 teaspoons of honey
I used 3 slices of fresh ginger root as well as the ground.
6-8 cloves of garlic
1/4 cup of white wine.
I kept the spice to same due to having a small child and just adjusted on my own plate.
I omitted the cornstarch, I found no need for it.  The sauce thickened lovely on it's own.

I used beef instead of shrimp.

All in all excellent recipe :)

I read the reviews, tripled the sauce, added the veggies, etc... and as this was cooking I realized I was making a Green Giant Create-A-Meal.  Seriously, if you've ever had the Szechwan Create-A-Meal, this is the same thing except with more work and actually less flavor.  They even include peanuts and awesome veggies in the package- all you add is the meat.  Soooo, while this was pretty good (but didn't have nearly the flavor I thought it would) next time I will stick with my quick, easy, and tasty Green Giant Create-A-Meal.

text:
This was absolutely delicious. I just have one recommendation for people using frozen cooked shrimp... make sure you defrost it and drain it well. If you do not do this, the shrimp will let out a lot of liquid in the pan, and you will end up with a big watery mess. What a great alternative to ordering in Chinese food! Making this at home cost me less than half of what ordering in would have!

A definite keeper!!  I did use fresh ginger root minced instead of ground ginger and raw shrimp. Also cooked the garlic, green onion and shrimp in toasted sesame oil. I doubled the sauce and added sesame seeds, bamboo shoots and water chestnuts to the shrimp and sauce for that Asian feel. I served it on Basmati Rice. Will be making again and again, thanks so much for sharing!!!

text:
This was great!  I make a lot of Chinese at home and the recipes can get complicated.  It's nice to find a recipe like this once in a while that is easy and quick to make, and really tastes good.  I always add more garlic and used chili oil instead of pepper flakes (some like it hot, as they say).  I made the dish through the sauce stage, adding a little dry sherry so it could simmer until I was ready to eat.  Then to keep the shrimp from over cooking, I tossed it into the sauce at the very end, and let is cook until the shrimp was opaque.  Very tastee!

it's quick!!!!!!!

I used 1/8 tsp and it was the perfect amount of heat for me.  This dish was definitely good and I would make it again maybe even using chicken.

text:
This is definitely a keeper!being Chinese myself,I am even impressed by how easy and quickly you can get this meal ready and how tasty it is! Will definitely triple the sauce though to get a nice sauce on my rice! Use raw shrimps adds freshness to the flavor, dry the shrimps with kitchen towel to make sure they fry nicely in the pan. Make sure you take them out after abt 80% done,and throw them back in after veges and sauce are ready. In this way the shrimps are done just right and are never tough.

text:
So YUMMY! We have made this twice in a row (since discovering it two days ago). Everyone loved it, and wanted more. The second day, we used chicken breasts instead of shrimp. Turned out just as delicious. I did make some slight changes. I added more red pepper, more veggies, used fresh ginger, used sesame oil instead of vegetable oil, used less ketchup (the first time I made it with the amount in the recipe, it was a bit too ketchup-y for us), and added a pinch or two of sugar to the sauce. I will definitely be making this again! Thank you FOODGU1 for the recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
Very versatile recipe!  For my first time making it, I tweaked it a little--okay, maybe I tweaked it a LOT.  Instead of shrimp, green onions, and garlic, I used a 1-lb bag of deluxe stir-fry veggie mix and 3/4 lb of sliced up pork chops.  After stir-frying those for 7 minutes in sesame oil (more oriental-inspired than vegetable oil), I added the sauce in (which I doubled, except for the cayenne--just added a pinch of that) and ta-da!  I was done within ten minutes.  Was totally delicious (though I think I won't eliminate the garlic next time; it did end up a little bland).

userID:
14757395
Display Name:
TheCookee
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe twice, and every time I have it, it never lets me down. I have a 6 month old and a 4 year old. I'm a stay at home mom and so cooking quick foods that allow me to get back to tending to the little one are a must. This meal is actually made in 20 minutes. Now for me, I actually do use raw shrimp instead of pre-cooked because I think it retains it's moisture much better so it does take a bit longer for me. The juices keep the shrimp succulent, so I don't mind the sacrifice in time amounting to about 3-6 minutes. My daughter is use to spicer foods and loved it (the honey flavor in the sauce I think is what she likes the most). Overall, a simple to make dish that packs a lot of flavor and punch. If your child is sensitive to spicy flavors, just cut back on the crushed red pepper, but you will end up with a sweeter shrimp so it won't be "schezwan" persay. This is also a good recipe to just make batches of and freeze for quick meals. I also would recommend coconut rice with this (that is what we eat it with). You can store the coconut rice in your fridge in a closed container for several days and you'll have an easy dinner to whip up in the event you are short on time or just plain tired!

city:

country:
None
text:
I searched on and off for probably more than a year, looking for the perfect sauce for my homemade stir-fry. THIS IS IT. It is perfectly spicy and flavorful, and completely healthy (I leave out the cornstarch, because I don't need it to be thick -- runny is perfectly fine!) I double this recipe and make it as a sauce, to go with my 8-10 cups of chopped veggies (I use a whole onion, several carrots, broccoli, and two colored peppers) and 1 lb of diced cooked chicken breast. It is PERFECT. After my chicken and veggies are cooked and combined, I throw this sauce in the pan over them all, let it simmer for a bit, and eat it  over rice. We have this for dinner twice once a month; it is my go-to for stir-fry now. And it's not too spicy for my less-than-two-year-old (although she handles spicy things well). I am SO grateful I found this :)

My man and I love this Chinese dish. I did make a few changes though. Served it over rice and we both went YUM!!

text:
It's so quick/easy to make and delicious. I grated some fresh ginger instead of using ground, and sesame oil instead of vegetable oil. I love using sesame oil in "Asian" dishes -- it's so much more fragrant than vegetable, canola, or even olive oil. If you've never tried it, you must try it. I also doubled the sauce and added a 1 lb bag of frozen mixed veggies. YUM!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We just made this for dinner tonight. It's fast, easy, and low fat--just what I was looking for.  I only made a few changes, I used fresh ginger, left out the red pepper flakes (to make this kid-friendly), and used half the amount of oil.  I marinated the shrimp in the sauce for 30 minutes before adding the cornstarch, then while frying the shrimp added the cornstarch to the sauce.  I fried up some shredded carrots, shallots, and red bell pepper with the shrimp and served with rice and roasted broccoli (I thought the crunchy texture of the roasted broccoli really complemented this!).  My picky toddler took one bite and then refused to eat anymore (as normal) but then when he thought we weren't looking shoveled the rest into his mouth--he completely cleaned his plate.  Delicious and easy!

text:
This is a really good recipe that is very easy to make.  Don't make my mistake.  I didn't let the shrimp thaw all the way before I put it in the skillet.  This of course created a lot of water.  I did drain the water with a paper towel before I added the mix.  But I wonder how much garlic flavoring I lost.  So let shrimp thaw first and pat dry with paper towel.  Even though I made that mistake the shrimp was still very good. Oh. Liked the review that suggested using raw shrimp b/c they cook so fast.  This is a great tip.

text:
OMG!  This recipe is shrimpaliscious.  I used 2 elephant garlic cloves which was perfect for the dish.  Didn't have any crushed red pepper------and I'm glad-----it was perfect without it.  I also used raw shrimp, which I added to the garlic and green onions only after this mixture cooked for at least 3 minutes-----just until the garlic was a golden color.  Cooking time for the shrimp was about an additional 3-4 minutes----just until it was nicely pink. . Final result-----shrimptabulous!

Last thought, to lower sodium use low sodium soy sauce and maybe fresh diced tomatoes from my garden??? in place of ketchup.

I used chopped ginger root instead of powdered ginger and it came out perfectly. This pairs really well with sautéed veggies and rice. Display Name:
Summer421

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This review is just for the sauce--I made a chicken and vegetable stir-fry. I have to say I was more than a little nervous when the sauce was just mixed but wasn't thickened. It didn't particularly taste good and the cornstarch gave it a grainy taste and texture and the crushed red pepper made it surprisingly spicy--and I love spicy food. The ketchup seemed to be the only flavor that was coming through and that wasn't exactly what I was going for.   So I started thinking "who are all of the people who rated this so high?" Are they just all tasteless semi-homemade cooks? I almost threw out the sauce completely after I started fretting about ruining my $12 package of m organic chicken with company on the way. But I trusted in the reviews and I was so glad that I did! My mother LITERALLY licked her plate and my 10 year old picky nephew went back for 3rds. Even my naysaying husband who is always saying that Asian food is impossible for non-Asians to pull off was thoroughly impressed. I only wished I had made more.  I made the sauce exactly as specified in the recipes but at the last moment in panic I added a squirt of honey. It all worked beautifully. What I made: I cubed and marinated the chicken in a ginger soy marinade while I prepped the veggies. I cut up broccoli, onions, red pepper, bok choy and sliced garlic. I cooked the chicken first and then set it aside while I cooked the veggies. At the end I added the sauce and added the chicken back in until the sauce thickened. Yum

text:
As of today, I have prepared 559 different recipes from the allrecipes website. This five-star Asian recipe is definitely in the top 10% of those I have tried. I am Chinese food aficionado. Chinese is my very favorite ethnic food category and given a choice, I would eat Chinese food three or four times every week. Szechwan Chicken is one of my favorite dishes, so when I discovered this recipe, I had the strong sense that I would like it. Like it? My entire family loved it. Admittedly, it's not the best I've ever had. Some Chinese restaurants are nearly unbeatable, but for something that can easily be prepared at home, and can be considered healthy eating to boot, that's enough to easily make this a five star recipe. I paired it with couscous, added some water chestnuts, used a two-pound bag of shrimp, and quadrupled the sauce. It was perfect; fan-stinkin'-tastic!

text:
This is a flavorful and delicious shrimp dish with just the right amount of heat.  And, it's an absolute snap to make. Use fresh ginger if you have it, as it really adds flavor.  I also use raw shrimp instead of already cooked shrimp because shrimp cooks so quickly.  This recipe has become one of my go-to recipes for when I don't want to spend a lot of time cooking but want to make something tasty and fresh for my family.

text:
Shallow flavor. It was totally edible, no one complained. but I think with some nice fresh ingredients like real ginger it could have really benefited. On the other hand, it was super quick and easy to make! Also, DO NOT use already cooked shrimp. Even with uncooked raw shrimp you're going to have to be seriously watching the shrimp before it gets overcooked or too tough.

Just to reiterate: Things I would change: Fresh uncooked shrimp, real ginger. It'd probably be a better dish then. Good luck!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/925555.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Bought the House of Tsang pre-made szechuan sauce to cut out half the time.  Added pea chutes, bean sprouts, carrot matchsticks, sliced red and green peppers and sauteed them in a wok for about 10 minutes so they had that charred look to them before adding the shrimp and szechuan sauce.  I made some brown rice ahead of time and refrigerated it so it cooked up nicely as fried rice in a cast iron pan.  I made a whole in the middle of the fried rice and scrambled two eggs.  After the stir fry was done and the shrimp were opaque, I blended with the fried rice and served everything together in one dish.  The House of Tsang szechuan sauce was perfect but is pretty spicy, so be sure not to add too too much just for the color if you can't take the heat.

text:
This recipe is a keeper. I made some changes. I don't use ketchup so didn't have any. The cooked shrimp were from a frozen shrimp cocktail so I used the cocktail sauce instead of ketchup. I used fresh ginger,  as another reviewer suggested(I like it better also.) I added a bag of frozen Birdseye Broccoli Stir fry, I put the veg in first and let it cook and the pan dry out. Then added the garlic and scallions. I was afraid of overcooking the cooked shrimp, so I put them in at the very last second, even after the sauce, and just stirred through to warm the shrimp and coat with sauce. I served it over rice. Yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The ratio of quick, tasty and low cal makes this an easy 5 star.  

I'll summarize a few of the other reviews but first my own suggestion:

Suggestion: Use a little less corn starch if you want sauce for your rice. The amount given gives a glaze rather than a sauce. 

Make double sauce: YES, DEFINITELY! Especially if you want some on your rice. 

Use fresh shrimp: YES, so much fresher tasting and the shrimp don't get over done.

No Taste: Well either you are used to REALLY spicy food or your red pepper flakes are years old. They do loose their flavor after a while.

Tastes like ketchup: I didn't find that to be true at all, but I blended the sauce ingredients with a whisk very well, and had fresh ingredients.

All in all - we loved it, stuck to our diet and it was quick and easy for a Friday after a long long day of work. BRAVO

text:
OMG, amazing! I have made many stir-frys in my day and this was absolutely the best one I have EVER made. I changed nothing in the sauce except using chicken broth instead of water, and because I had no honey, used about 2 tsp of maple syrup (tripled the ingredients for more sauce). The sauce was fabulous! I'm skeptical when a recipe calls for ketchup and another sweet ingredient like honey, but this was just the right amount of spice and sweet (neither me nor my family like alot of sweet in our meals). It worked soooo well! Tripled the sauce because I used jumbo shrimp and added lots of veggies, served it over chow mein noodles. Absolutely to die for and I will never buy stir-fry sauce again. Thank you FOODGU1! Everyone in the family absolutely loved it!!

text:
Very Tasty. I added garlic to the sauce instead of the shrimp and blended it in the small food processor.  Note the sauce burns easily and thickens quickly so I added a 1/2 cup of Campbell's chicken broth. I also omited the red pepper and included about 2 cups of pre-cooked vegetables (carrot, bok choy and sugar snap peas).  Added cashews and served over rice.

text:
These were really good!!  I served mine over a bed of spinach (not wilted or cooked), only because I was serving a Creamy Avocado Pasta alongside, and I wanted each dish to 'stand alone' so to speak.  I opted to use fresh ginger instead of ground as I felt it went better (typically have only used ground ginger in baking that I recall).  I did not have any green onions, so used a 3 onion mixture (dried) to saute with my garlic.  This was quick to throw together, definitely spicy mixed with a hint of sweetness.  Would be even better served over rice, opposed to the way I served it (over the spinach - LOL)!!  Great :)

text:
This recipe was outstanding and super easy. I did make a few variations.  I mixed all the ingredients together (less 1/2 tsp of cornstarch) to make a marinade.  I put the shrimp on several skewers, marinated them for 10 minutes, and grilled them.  I heated the remaining marinate for a minutes until cooked through and bubbly. I served the skewers over jasmine rice and garnished it with sliced green onions and cilantro.  I had a leftover yam so I made yam chips...Wow!

text:
I made this for the boyfriend and he was pleased. I intended to make it just like the recipe stated. However, I brought all the ingredients over to cook and when I got to the honey I noticed I forgot. No problem I thought because I'm sure his family has some. Nope! Sugar. None! Brown sugar. Nada. His family are all diabetics! Who doesn't have ANYTHING sweet in their house. Finally I came across I can of mandarin oranges in light syrup. So I decided to go out on a limb and use the syrup instead. It was good!! Who would thought...ORANGES! The flavors had a lot of depth. It was the right mix of hot and sweet. My boyfriend was like how did you know to do that? I added a some steamed broccoli in the with the shrimp and poured over a batch of white rice. I sprinkled black pepper over the finished product for presentation. I was impressed with myself!

text:
This turned out awesome. I do have to admit I made some small changes. You HAVE TO double the sauce. You just don't get enough sauce with this recipe. I used Chinese noodles as some suggested. I also added five spice, but I'm sure it tasted fine without it. I love vegies and shrimp so I probably threw in some extra. Great recipe poster.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is very easy and quite good, but I think that the sauce needs more of a pop of flavor. I would recommend that you add the garlic, FRESH grated ginger, and scallions to the sauce, then add sauce at the end as the recipe directs. That way the garlic and scallions aren't overcooked. The fresh ginger is really needed too. Additionally, it's a good idea for you to double the sauce and add veggie to the dish instead of having to make a second veggie dish. Just saute some broccoli or add frozen vegetables to the dish along with the shrimp. Yum!

Display Name:
Lyrelle

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really delicious and yummy. I cut down a bit on the spice (just a pinch of red pepper) for personal preference and used a pre-frozen, deveined and headless shrimp package. Usually I like to use fresh shrimp for cooking but since this recipe has so much flavor from the sauce, it really doesn't matter. Make sure to use large shrimps if you can, otherwise cooking it with the sauce can cause it to pretty much disintegrate. I also recommend that you thicken it up with a slurry of cornstarch if you want to put some sauce on rice. Stir-frying or steaming some green vegetables to mix in with it is a great idea too. Otherwise, the flavors are great! Definitely a keeper for my arsenal of easy meals.

text:
We really liked this and as the designated cook who's currently 8 mos. pregnant, I appreciated the ease and quickness that this came together!! I followed the recipe as written with the exception of adding an additional 1/4 tsp red pepper (my son wasn't home and DH and I like it hot!). Also, I did NOT precook the shrimp. Overcooked shrimp is rubbery so I just added it raw and cooked it until opaque before adding the sauce. To me, it lacked a little something though so I think I'll try adding some rice wine vinegar to the sauce next go-round.

text:
So easy, and the sauce is delicious!  Hands down, this is my boyfriend's favorite dish!  I double all ingredients (except the shrimp), prepare as stated, and serve over rice (Minute rice at that, which makes the meal even easier and super fast).  He eats the entire pound of shrimp himself - in one helping!   I've also tripled the sauce and added some leftover boneless pork chops cut into strips in with the shrimp.  Delicious, and it makes the dish friendly for those who don't eat seafood (like ME!), because the shrimp flavor doesn't permeate the sauce or the pork!  (Phew!)  If I could have rated it six stars, I would have!

I gave this recipe 4 stars because I didn't have all the ingredients so I had to improvise. If it tasted as good with my substitutes, I would've given it 5. Display Name:
Dawn

2

91

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/588990.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW - this is so good.  I made minor changes, I used a pound of raw shrimp and cooked that a bit before adding the sauce.  I tripled the sauce and it was a perfect amount.  However, next time I won't triple the corn starch because it got really thick, I think just doubling the cornstarch and tripling the rest would be perfect.  I served it with vegetable fried rice and that was a perfect compliment to this spicy shrimp.   I want to note that you really don't want to taste the sauce before it's cooked because it definitely tastes like ketchup with some stuff in it, but once the heat is put to it and it simmers it is amazing.  My daughter said it was much better than any take-out due to the great flavor and because it wasn't greasy like a lot of take-out Chinese food can be. OK - one other thing I did - I have this obsession with making stock, so I just cooked the shrimp shells in about 1/2 cup of water for about 10 minutes till it reduced in half and then added the resulting stock to the sauce.

If shrimp is not on sale, I plan to use thinly cut chicken strips and use this sauce, after stir frying the chicken.  Served with white rice, sauce was excellent over the rice.  Thanks for sharing.

country:

text:
DELICIOUS! Great flavor for such a quick and easy  recipe! I tripled the amount of sauce (because I wanted a lot of sauce to serve over rice) with the following changes: 12 tbsp water, 8 tbsp ketchup, 4 tbsp soy sauce, 3 tsp honey, 4 tsp cornstarch, 3/4 tsp ground ginger, and 1 1/2 tsp crushed red pepper. I like spicy food but if you don't I would recommend cutting down the crushed red pepper. I also used 1 lb cooked shrimp, 4 tbsp minced garlic and 1/2 cup sliced green onions. I served this over white rice and made the Tasty Green Beens (on this site) as a side. It was a perfect, quick, and most importantly TASTY dinner fully made in about 40-45 min including prep time!

Seriously, could this recipe be any easier or quicker...and it is so good!  I was surprised, as I am not a ketchup fan.  The recipe is great as is, but I have made a few changes for my family. I add some veggies, and viola, delish meal in minutes.  Thank you so much for posting the recipe!

text:
This was very good and easy.  I used raw shrimp (1 pound) since they cook so fast.  I doubled the sauce as everyone recommended and was glad I did.  Served over steamed rice.  This was enough for one generous serving each for my daughter and me.  You will want to multiply the recipe if you are serving more than two people.

Edit:  Made this again 8/15/10.  Tripled the sauce, used 1 lb. raw shrimp, also stir fried some fresh broccoli.  Boiled 8 oz. whole wheat fettuccine and tossed this in at the end to make a lo mein.   Fantastic!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/166962.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This seems to be either a "Gimme More" or "Throw It Out" dish.  Just did not like the sauce at all.  I  like Szechwan recipies, especially the very spicy ones, and have made a minor hobby of cooking Szechwan meals.  I agree with all those who say this sauce is not representative of most Szechwan sauces. Most call for chicken or veal broth or stock instead of water, although not all. Many also call for various amounts of vinegar  And, while not unique by any means, honey is not an ingredient common to the majority of sauces. My advice is, make the sauce, try it.  If you don't like, throw it out.  If you do, then by all means, put it on your shrimp and enjoy.

text:
This was really yummy, but I did add a few of my own touches. I sauteed the shrimp until almost done, then removed to a plate. Steamed broccoli and carrots in the microwave for 5 minutes, added to pan with garlic and sauce until the sauce started to thicken. Then I added the shrimp back in until it was cooked through. My husband loved this and after we were finished with dinner, he said "Now you know why I don't like ordering in Chinese. This is much better." So, thank you, for a wonderful base recipe on which we can all build upon. Oh - and by the way .... the leftovers were incredible because the flavors in the sauce intensified.

This recipe has way too much corn starch for the amount of sauce (which is not really enough anyway). Even after thinning the sauce, I wasn't impressed with the flavor. The shrimp should be added at the last minute to heat, since they are already cooked, or they will end up tough. I can save the leftovers by adding and tweaking, but can't really recommend this recipe as it is written. Sorry!

This recipe was so good.  I was a little intimated because although my favorite kind of food is asian, that is what I cook the least of.  So, I was nervous about it not tasting like what I get in the authentic "restaurants".  And to my surprise it was just as good, if not better. I did add some sauted zucchini, mushrooms and broccoli and tripled the sauce and I made a side of white rice and they were perfect compliments.

WOW!! This was sooooo DELICIOUS!! I would not have thought to mix these ingredients together to make a sauce but it really was good! I did double the ginger to give it a more authentic chinese restaurant taste! I sauteed white onions, bell pepper, and minced garlic first. Then added some frozen stir-fry vegetables that I steamed in the microwave. I also used RAW shrimp (as suggested by another reviewer because i feared if they were pre-cooked they would turn out tough) SO GLAD I DID!! Anyway I then followed the recipe as written, cooking until the shrimp were pink and tender (about 5 minutes) It was great! Even my VERY picky boyfriend asked for seconds!!! I will defintely be keeping this recipe on hand!

text:
This is by far the best szechwan shrimp I have ever had - anywhere!  It is simply delicious.  I'm a novice cook, and I prepared this with no problem at all.  I will say that if you don't like spicy foods to be VERY CAREFUL with how much of the red peppers you add.  I wasn't really paying attention and must have dumped a ton in there, because the dish was way too hot (my fault though, not the recipe's!).  You might want to omit the red peppers all together the first time.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/82171.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last night and I loved it! Being a vegetarian however, I decided to put my own twist on it. For the portion of the sauce, I increased it to a 6 serving portion, and used tofu instead of shrimp. I browned the tofu in olive oil first, then added the onion and garlic when the tofu was slightly browned on all sides. After heating the garlic and onion for 30 seconds or so on medium heat, I added about a pound of mixed vegetables to the wok and turned the heat up to med-high for several minutes. When the veggies started to soften I added the sauce and reduced the heat back to medium. This took only about 10 minutes total, and was totally rockin' when it was finished. Served over white rice, it was just fantastic! I hate leftovers, but this was still awesome when I reheated it today! Thanks!

text:
The taste was good but I used tomato sauce instead of ketchup. Ketchup has extra flavours that can really kill the Asian flavor in this recipe. For the first time, I used ketchup and wasn`t satisfied with the flavor at all. Using plain tomato sauce, the flavor is much better. For this quantity of shrimp I didn`t need cornstarch at all, so next time I would increase the sauce ingredients. I am not a Chinese cuisine expert, but I wish the taste were more Asian. Good, but not the same I have tried in Chinese restaurants.

text:
Delicious! I made a few changes.

I diced a single skinless chicken breast, and threw the piece in a frying pan for a few minutes. While the chicken was cooking, I sprinkled curry powder all over it, in addition to some red pepper. 

I made the sauce described in the recipe, and tossed it with the chicken in the pan for a few minutes. 

I then made Uncle Ben's microwavable long grain and wild rice, and mixed in a little over half of the chicken. It was a huge meal for one person, plus it's healthy, plus I have a ton left over :).

Thanks for the great recipe!

*5* Stars!! This recipe couldn't be easier!  Doubled the sauce (not the cornstarch) and I used teryaki sauce in place of the soy sauce only bc it's all I had on hand.  (I'm sure soy sauce would be better, but this wasn't a bad substitution)  Also, I used some leftover cooked rotisserie chicken (no skin).  I couldn't face chicken salad again for lunch and thought I'd give this a try.  This was just as fast or faster than making a lunch of soup and sandwich.  I will definitely make this again for dinner - especially when I'm facing a time crunch to get dinner on the table.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was really worried about this being too sweet or ketchup-y so I used tomato sauce instead of ketchup.  I think next time, I'm going to take the plunge and use ketchup because after tasting regular tomato sauce, I don't think ketchup will "get in the way" and it will be much more convenient!  I doubled everything except for the shrimp, added a 16 oz bag of stir-fry veggies, and served over brown rice.  I also added more crushed red pepper (1 1/2 tsp total) and didn't think it was even close to being too spicy.  I 1 tsp of used fresh, grated ginger (if you've never cooked with fresh ginger before, you've GOT to give it a try -- the powdered stuff doesn't even taste like the real stuff, and it's REALLY not as intimidating as it sounds).  All in all, this was decent.  The szechwan flavor I was looking for was THERE, it just wasn't as strong as I like it.  I'm new to Asian cooking so I'll play around with it a bit more.  Definitely NOT a bad dish, though!!

Display Name:
DMR
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband really liked this dish. We ate it last night and he brought the leftovers for lunch today. I just received him an e-mail from him here at work saying that he just finished eating his lunch and that it was "soooooooo good". I added some frozen stir fry veggies and doubled the sauce as others suggested. I actually didn't feel the need to double the sauce because it was a little "soupy" for me. Instead of ketchup, I used tomato paste and when I added the crushed red pepper, I didn't think it was spicy enough. Then I added the corn starch and when everything started fizzing, THAT'S when I could taste the heat. Unfortunately for me, I had added a little more crushed red pepper because I didn't think it was going to be enough spice. Guess I should've waited until everything was blended together because it was HOT! My husband loves hot and spicy dishes so this is probably why he was such a fan of this one. Definitely not like the typical szechwan shrimp in Chinese restaurants but it was still tasty. The color threw me off too. I wasn't a fan of the sauce color because it made me think that I was eating an italian marinara sauce or something. I was so pleased that this was so easy to prepare and so quick. I served this with white rice. Mine definitely did not look like the photo! I guess I was expecting something a little different based on the picture.

My family enjoyed this dish; it was very tasty. I don't think it tasted anything like the real Szechwan Shrimp served at most Chinese restaurants though. As suggested by other reviewers, I tripled the ingredients for the sauce, and I doubled the green onions, garlic, and shrimps, and added 2 Tbsp. fresh lemon juice. I also added about a tsp. of sesame oil. Will be making this again.

Really nice, easy and super fast recipe for a weeknight. The sauce is wonderful and you can spice it up to the level of heat you desire through the amount of chili flakes you add. I like the flexibility of this recipe. You can add things like red pepper slices, bean sprouts, pineapple chunks, mushrooms or whatever because it will never disappoint.  You can counterbalance the spice with a little bit of sugar as well if you  lean toward a more sweet and sour flavour. Thank you for a great go-to recipe.

text:
This dish was very easy to make, very healthy, and very delicious. As others suggested I doubled the sauce, and I was glad I did since it was so delicious. It gave me enough to spoon over a riced cauliflower stir-fry side dish (frozen from Trader Joes). I used 1 tsp. of ginger paste instead of the ground ginger, which added some good flavor. I'm sensitive to spicy foods, so I cut the red pepper in half, but I felt like it would have been fine to increase it. It didn't end up being too spicy for me. Overall, this was a great recipe that I'll defintely make again.

This is glop! The only changes I made were to use fresh shrimp, fresh ginger, and fresh garlic! I was naturally suspicious of a Chinese recipe that includes catsup, but thought I’d give it a try. If you have never actually eaten Chinese food prepared in San Francisco , New York City, Washington DC or China, chances are you will think this is tasty. And, if your Hubby and children think it’s good, by all means, prepare it for them... chances are they will never know the difference!

userID:
20212293
Display Name:
Shoshana
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
44
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7219798.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a flavorful and healthy dinner to make with shrimp I had gotten on sale, along with a lovely assortment of vegetables. This recipe was perfect as I had all the sauce ingredients in the house.  I made the sauce the day before, allowing the flavors to blend in the fridge, and I also doubled it as I wanted a sauce for brown rice.  I didn’t have green onions, so I used a shallot, thinly sliced.  I sautéed the shallot and garlic for 2mns, then added the shrimp until they just turned pink. I removed the shrimp and started adding my assortment of cut-up veggies to the pan, heavier ones like carrots 1st, ending with sliced baby bok choy. I poured the sauce into the vegetable mixture to coat, covered the pan & brought it to a light boil. I added the shrimp back in, tossed everything about for about another minute. Served it over the brown rice with the extra sauce. I cut back on the red pepper as we don’t like things super hot, but enough to add flavor. It was a beautiful presentation, the flavors in the sauce blended so well that we put it on our salads also. Next time I make it, I will use fresh ginger. Really good recipe as is, and easy enough to add the fresh veggies as I did.

text:
Very flavorful.  I added a bit more crushed pepper, as we like spicy. But was a wee bit too spicy. I tripled the sauce, except the water and cornstarch. Made a few changes. Used garlic chili sauce instead of the ketchup, as a lot of the reviews were not fond of the strong ketchup flavor, added a bit of fresh lime juice to the sauce. Also, because my fiance prefers it, I mixed some rice in with  the shrimp before adding the sauce.
Would definitely make this again

country:
None
text:
This was DELICIOUS!  I doubled the sauce, which I made in a pot instead of mixing in a bowl.  I heated it on low and let it after simmer so the flavors could meld together.  I also added the cornstarch (mixed with water to make a slurry) after the sauce had simmered and stirred for about 1 minute until it had a nice consistency.  


Next I sauteed the onion and garlic in a frying pan and added that to the sauce.  I then cooked fresh shrimp in the frying pan and stirred them into the sauce.  Served it over white rice and enjoyed a fabulous dinner!

I will definitely make this again...thank you for a great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
An excellent, simple recipe. At first I was hesitant to make it because it called for ketchup, which I automatically assumed would make it subpar and "inauthentic". But my wife (who is Chinese) told me many good Chinese restaurants actually use ketchup when making certain dishes like this. I used 1/2 lb. raw shrimp and slightly increased amount of each ingredient accordingly, which included TJ's ketchup (no added corn syrup), about 1/2 tsp. finely diced FRESH ginger and a little extra crushed red pepper for more flavor. My wife thought it was great and said the leftovers tasted even better when warmed up the next day for lunch. An ideal side dish is broccoli florets quickly stir-fried in minced garlic and salt.

SUPER TENDER, plus a springy bite.

I prefer to use raw jumbo shrimp. By cooking the shell the liquid can be added to soup stock. Raw shrimp cooks so  quickly that I’d be afraid of overcooking the cooked shrimp that this recepie calls for winiding up with a rubbery consistency. I also like to add in some vegetables like sugar snap peas, snow peas, mushrooms and broccoli to make a complete meal. Yum!

text:
This was delicious! I doubled the sauce and added a little extra honey and soy sauce.  I used a yellow onion chopped in 1 inch pieces because I didn’t have green onions. I also added a red bell pepper, broccoli and long sliced baby carrots. I stir fried all the veggies together and then added shrimp. I only used 1/4 t of red pepper flakes because we don’t like extra hotness.  I served it over white rice. My 95 year old mother, who lives with us, voluntarily said it was really good...and that’s unusual. The sauce would also be delicious with chicken.
