city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have done this recipe twice so far. Once with shrimps then with white fish, in both trials I added some frozen vegetables.
I cutted the white fish in chunky pieces and cooked it with the onion and garlic. Then added the frozen vegetables until they were tender before adding the mixture.
When doing the mixture I didn't have corn starch so I used regular flour. Then discovered that I've ran out of honey, so I used regular white sugar.
Even with all those changes, the final dish was a big hit in our house.
Will definitely cook it when the craving for a spicy Chinese recipe is asked for.

Display Name:
shonne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/763929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was amazingly good!  I sauteed sliced onions and carrots in canola oil for about 5 minutes.  I added minced garlic, bean sprouts, sliced portobello mushrooms, and cauliflower rice and stir fried for about 3 minutes before adding in shrimp and sauce.  Cooked an additional 7 minutes stirring frequently until shrimp was cooked thoroughly.  I did not have green onions or ketchup,  I substituted tomato sauce for ketchup and added a little sugar and corn syrup (about a 1/4 teaspoon each).  I doubled the sauce as recommended and used only half of the red pepper.  I love spicy but was being considerate of others.  I found it to have plenty of heat.  I didn't want to stop eating it and can hardly wait to eat the leftovers today.  I will make this over and over again for sure!  Great recipe!

5

country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  I doubled the sauce (per everyone's instructions) and used some substitutions.  I didn't want to cook with ketchup so replaced with tomato paste, used fresh raw shrimp instead of precooked, and used fresh ginger.  After cooking the shrimp in the garlic and green onion for a minute or so I added fresh stir fry vegetables and cooked a few more minutes until the shrimp was done.  Then added the sauce and some snow peas.  I served over Jasmine rice.  Family loved including my 10 year old daughter who normally doesn't like spicy dishes.

text:
I bought 1 1/2 pounds of large raw shrimp for my family, double the sauce (as I read in previous reviews, glad I did).  I blanched and sautéed some broccoli before I started, then added the shrimp to the pan, half way thru cooking I added the sautéed broccoli and sauce and garlic ( fearing the broccoli would scorch if added in the beginning) and garnished with the sliced scallions.  This is absolutely going on the "make again list". I served it with basmati rice.  It's a keeper!

Loved this very easy recipe.... I tweaked it a bit to make it more of a full entree by adding (1) Green Pepper and (1/2) large onion both cubed.  Add it in with the green onions to give a chance to soften a bit.  Next time will add small can of bamboo shoots as well.  And as far as the 'heat' not very hot - dont have to add the pepper flakes, but i actually put a little more in - tweak as you want depending on taste

text:
I make lots of recipes from this site. This is the first one I've ever rated. Loved it! Hubby did too. He couldn't rave enough over it! We followed the sauce recipe exactly, with one tiny exception to the sauce. We added a tiny dash of Sriracha sauce (I do mean tiny, a little goes a long ways). We like it pretty spicy around here. We doubled the batch of sauce, cooking the shrimp without peeling or deveining. Added them to the sauce when perfectly pink. The sauce thickens very quickly, so we had it ready to go. We just ate the shrimp and sauce. If you want to add veggies and rice or noodles, I would recommend tripling or quadrupling the sauce. This would be good with both. I also think it would go well with chicken or pork. Great recipe! Delicious, and very adaptable. Thanks for sharing.

This is a fantastic,easy and quick recipe to pull together.  Each time I've made it I've tripled the ingredients. text:
This is quite good.  It throws together quickly and uses ingredients you already have on hand.  I added some strips of fresh red, yellow and orange peppers along with the green onion.  I sauteed those until crisp tender then added the garlic for 30 seconds before tossing in the fresh shrimp.  I added the sauce (which I doubled) and it only took a few minutes until the sauce was bubbling and thick.  I served this over lo mein noodles where the extra sauce came in handy.  We like the heat so the red pepper amount worked for us. The peppers were a great addition and I wish that I had added some other veggies as well to round out the dish a bit more.  Easy, fast, and yummy!

text:
I've made this several times. The sauce, which is the basis of this recipe is excellent and a great foundation for any stir-fry. I make sauce just as the recipe calls for. It's very flavorful and has quite a kick. (I'd cut down on the red pepper if you don't like spicy.) I always make the sauce first then stir-fry raw shrimp and whatever vegetables  I'm feeling and add the sauce at the end. It's a fast healthy meal. If you add veggies, I'd definitely double the sauce. I do and it's perfect amount  to serve over rice.

text:
Yum! Added corn starch coated cubes of chicken thighs (about 3 lbs), fried beforehand, frozen broccoli 1/2 big bag, steamed beforehand, and 1 chopped onion and 1 green pepper- stir fried beforehand- then heated sauce and raw shrimp for about 4 minutes.  Put a scoop of jasmine rice, then a scoop of chicken, then vegetables, then sauce and shrimp- Super good- tasted like Dragon and Phoenix- really great- just took longer than 20 minutes due to the addition of cubed chicken thighs (had to cook in 4 rounds in a skillet)  and vegetables. Took about an hour total- Fantastic weekend dish! will definitely make again and again! I also added a little more soy sauce and doubled the sauce- it was just right!
2nd Review- just found out as I was preparing this dish that my husband ate the bag of shrimp we had in the freezer so here come the modifications :) I am using a bag of calamari and flaked fake crab meat instead of the shrimp. Tripled the sauce and also added a large head of chopped bok choy, a can of sliced water chestnuts and a can of sliced bamboo shoots. Also added half of the amount of fresh grated ginger and the other half powdered ginger. Serving over Jasmine Rice. I wish I had some fresh mushrooms to slice and add to this dish! Still Super!

text:
Really delicious simple recipe.  I used raw shrimp and just cooked until opaque before adding sauce.  I also cooked a bag of stir fry frozen vegetables in the microwave beforehand and tossed it in with the sauce.  I tripled the sauce and had plenty for serving with brown rice (and we like sauce).  However, I only doubled the red pepper and it was still very spicy.  I like heat, but others in my family thought it was too spicy and couldn't eat it - next time I will probably triple the sauce again but keep the pepper to 1/2 tsp.

None
text:
This recipe is so tasty and easy to make with ingredients most of us have on hand.  After making it several times in a month I started to make the sauce in a pint size mason jar and changing the servings to 16.  I'll use half the sauce for one meal and the other half gets used within a day or two for another meal.  The sauce goes equally well with chicken or just a mix of veggies.  I usually increase the red pepper and add fresh ginger if I have it on hand.  We like it spicy!

Delish, easy to make and low calorie!  I followed the sauce exactly as recommended except for substituting lite soy sauce.  I added cut up asparagus.  With adding a veggie, I would 1.5X the sauce next time.  I used small shrimp.  Served over jasmine 90 second (Uncle Ben's) rice and it was very filling! Only 175 calories per serving if you sub lite soy sauce and add asparagus (+210 for a serving of the rice)!

text:
Made this last night...my family loved it.  They like spicy food, so it was perfect, otherwise you may want to cut back on the red pepper... Also, I'd read in another review to try using raw peeled shrimp instead of already boiled shrimp... good idea... I did just that.  Only took about 2 minutes to cook them, and I had no problem with them turning out rubbery from being cooked twice.  Also, I used about twice as much shrimp sa the recipe called for just because I had that much... It was fine.  Don't need to double the recipe or anything else.

I give the recipe 4 stars as written here but 5 stars as I made it.  As mentioned in many of the reviews I made a few modifications.  I just can't help myself.  I added one small zucchini and one small yellow squash (both chopped medium) to the garlic and green onions to saute.  I doubled the sauce ingredients and added some Mongolian Hot Oil to the sauce and the shrimp veggie mixture ( while cooking).  Served over Basmati rice this was a complete hit.  As one user already expressed this was the best Asian dish I have EVER made at home.   Will adapt to chicken and maybe even beef.

None to spread on our rice.
I like to make a posted recipe and be satisfied with the flavor, as it is written.

This recipe is a winner. Big time. For the record, I doubled the sauce and used it for only two servings, and it was the perfect amount and perfect taste. As far as the rest of it, I tried to simplify things for myself as much as possible. I used pre-cooked but fresh cocktail shrimp, pre-cut green onions, pre-minced garlic and added microwave-steamed peas and carrots. The one thing that took the longest is the rice, and if I'd had the forethought to buy instanct rice, I would've done that too. Bravo, foodgu1, a fast and seriously delicious recipe.

text:
This recipe certainly is simple and quick to make, and my family enjoyed it.  I substituted fresh grated ginger for the ground ginger, and ignored the advice to double the sauce. I am completely baffled by the notion that this sauce needs to be doubled. There was plenty of sweet and spicy sticky sauce to go around. I did use the cooked frozen shrimp, and while that was tremendously easy, next time I will take the extra couple of minutes to use uncooked shrimp and cook it myself.  I think the end result would be better.

This wasn't bad, but it was far from great, I used raw shrimp, but other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. userID:
4399411
Display Name:
Jenlaur
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
73
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has to be one of the best dishes I have tried on Allrecipes. I made only minor changes. For the sauce, I tripled it. Also, some reviewers commented that the dish tasted too much like ketchup. I decreased the amount of ketchup by 1/3. For the shrimp, garlic and onions, I sauteed them all at the same time in olive oil (instead of vegetable oil) until the shrimp were opaque. I also steamed a bag of Asian veggies (for a minute or two less than the bag says or they will be too soft) and some pea pods (cause I love them). I prepared brown rice. I placed the rice on the plates and the veggies on top.  Then added the shrimp on top of the veggies.  This dish has just the right amount of spice. I would use everything (except maybe the ketchup) in the amounts stated in the recipe. Also, some of the reviewers commented that fresh ginger should be used. I really don't think it matters as the dish is spicy enough that you can't really tell if the ginger is ground or fresh.  I consider this recipe good enough to serve to company. This is definitely a keeper!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-09-11T18:32:32.947

text:
This is one of the best shrimp meals you can make and it always impresses! The sauce alone is amazing! Everyone always asks about it now and the best part about it is its VERY simple to make.  Just some advice: If you make a large batch, (Basically anything 2 pounds and above) be sure to drain most of the water before you put in the sauce.. If you don't, the flavor will be less "Flavorful."   I always make a little changes here and there to make it my own, but the recipe as a core, is one of the best shrimp recipes around!

userID:
2991034
Display Name:
LeopardMoth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
38
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/229777.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very quick and very good!  I didn't have quite all the ingredients on hand, but I was able to substitute.  My crushed red pepper was very old and didn't smell like anything, so I used cayenne instead.  I didn't have green onions or fresh garlic, so I used a frozen "seasoning mix" of chopped onion and red and green bell pepper, and granulated garlic.  My uncle is on a reduced salt diet, so I used low sodium soy sauce.    I tripled the sauce like others had, and it was just the right amount to toss into the egg noodles I served it with.  I was afraid I had used too much cayenne, so I added some (less spicy) salt-free peanut sauce.  That mellowed out the cayenne and preserved the Asian theme.  I had almond oil, so I used that instead of regular vegetable oil to give it another dimension.  I simmered the seasoning mix in the almond oil while I mixed the rest of the sauce ingredients.  I added the remainder of the sauce to the skillet, and put the egg noodles in boiling water.  When the egg noodles were done, I added the cooked shrimp to the skillet, stirred for a moment, turned off the heat, and stirred for another minute, then removed it from the heat.  I didn't want the shrimp to overcook, and it didn't.  The only reason I don't give this five stars is that it isn't the sort of thing I put in my mouth and think, "where have you been all my life?"  That would be a five-star recipe.  But this was very good and quick, which was just what I needed.  Thanks!!!  :)

This was excellent!  The flavors worked so well together.  I love spicy food and this definitely had a kick but not overpowering.  I made this alongside brown rice and sauteed onions, peppers and mushrooms.  And it made leftovers since it was just the hubby and I (I love when a good dinner makes enough for leftovers... it makes me look forward to work!).  I use natural Heinz ketchup (no HFCS) so all in all, this is a healthy, well-balanced, flavorful meal that will be made again and again!!

text:
great recipe!  didn't really change a thing besides tripling the sauce and adding a bag of fresh veggies (broccoli, snow peas, and carrots).  i began with the scallions and garlic in oil first.  then i added the shrimp and let them cook for several minutes.  meanwhile, i steam the vegetables in a different pot.  by the time the shrimp is cooked, the vegetables should be done.  i strain the vegetables and then add them, along with the sauce, to the shrimp and garlic and scallion mixture.  i served it over brown rice.  perfect!

userID:
102702
Display Name:
ZeldaSayre
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was quite good!  I always try to avoid changing things the first time around, but this time I couldn't quite do it.  I used raw shrimp instead of cooked and chicken broth instead of water because I had both; I didn't want to cook a separate vegetable, so I added broccoli, snow peas and shredded carrots.  To compensate for the extra ingredients, I tripled the sauce.  Honestly, I'm not sure I'd do that again; the sauce got exponentially less tasty as I increased it, growing slightly bitter from the ground ginger and crazy, crazy spicy.  In retrospect, it would have been a better dish if I'd used fewer veggies and only half the sauce.  This is all my fault, but learn from my mistakes!  Aside from my own mistakes, I thought the sauce was just a bit too ketchupy, thus the four stars.  Next time I might try subbing a tablespoon of hoisin for one of the tablespoons of ketchup.  Thanks for a great dinner, though!
Review:
Rating:
5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1735124.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this exactly as the recipe says.  Not bad but would be a lot better if you use uncooked shrimp.  I only had the shrimp in the pan for as long as it took for the sauce to thicken (maybe a minute) but the extra cooking still made them turn out tough and kind of rubbery.  Shrimp cooks so fast, using precooked shrimp really isn't much of a time saver and the texture could be soooo much better.  That said, the sauce is tasty and cooks up nicely - I love the idea of putting the cornstarch in with the wet ingredients instead of mixing it with water and adding it at the end - saves a step.

This is a simple, quick and delicious meal.  I made this for an unplanned dinner party and everyone raved.  Not only is it really quick to pull together, it was also a life saver because you will likely have all of the ingredients in your kitchen.  I made this without any "futzing" and it turned out extremely well.  I would recommend a light Chardonnay or possibly a Pinot Grigio as a sweeter wine to cut the nice heat of this dish.  THANKS FOR THIS ONE!

This was a magnificent recipe for how easy it was to make. Took me only 20 minutes, and it was very delicious. I added some broccoli in for good measure and it was awesome! I definitely suggest doubling, or tripling the sauce, as I tripled mine and it was the perfect amount with our added veggies. I would also suggest using raw shrimp, as others have stated, as it tastes much better. I used precooked shrimp and it was a little too chewy. Still magnificent though, thanks for this wonderful recipe!!

text:
This was VERY good.  I 2 & 1/2 times the sauced and added about 1 1/2 pounds of cooked shrimp (all I had). I cooked the garlic and onion in olive oil (rather than vegetable oil) until tender.  Then I put the cooked shrimp in just a couple of seconds before I added the sauce (just enough to slightly brown one side).  That helped keep the shrimp from over cooking.  I also used about 1t of fresh ginger (for 2 1/2 times the original recipe).  This did have a good kick.  I thought it was a bit too spicy BUT my husband and son loved the spicy kick.  Next time I think I will add just a little less red pepper.  They can always add more at the table.  I might also try making this with chicken....

text:
I was looking to try and re-create a dish I had in NYC recently (best shrimp I've ever had!) and this sounded pretty close, except that one was creamy so I subbed heavy cream for the h2o and although it wasn't the dish I was looking for, it came out VERY good!  I doubled all of the sauce ingredients except oil and used garlic powder cause I wanted a smooth creamy sauce (left green onions out too).  Only did 1t cornstarch though cause the cream made it thick already.  BF loved it! Served with bok choy and white rice and it was a super yummy meal... Will definately make again...

This recipe is AMAZING!  So fast, healthy and delicious!  Like other reviewers, I doubled the sauce and used fresh grated ginger root.  I used half the amount of crushed red pepper and that was plenty of heat for us.  I also only used half the amount of corn starch so the rice could soak up the sauce.  I plan on using this recipe with chicken - just add some veggies and you've got a complete meal!  Who would of ever thought ketchup would be so good in a Chinese dish?!

text:
DEFINITELY double the sauce if it is going over rice.  My husband and I made this tonight and did not change anything, except doubling the sauce.  We had steamed stir-fry veggies on the side, but would recommend tripling the sauce if you wanted to add veggies into the sauce.  When finished, it tasted like a very fresh Lean Cuisine.  Obviously healthy, but still very good.  We each love spice and added 10 drops of Sriracha sauce to the top, and that really increased the heat AND the flavor.  Much better!  Thanks for posting such a healthy and SUPER EASY recipe!  Certainly will make again!

text:
What a hit! Just the right amount of heat to satisfy all of us using the crushed red pepper flakes. After sauteeing the onion and garlic for thirty seconds, I stir-fried the shrimp until just pink. I removed the shrimp from the pan and stirred in steamed broccoli, carrots,and mushrooms, then I added the (tripled) sauce until hot and bubbly. Finally, I returned the shrimp to the mixture to heat them through.

text:
I followed this recipe to a tee, and the end result was a bit bland.  I was surprised at how quickly this meal cooked, it literally took 20 minutes.  The sauce started out a bit strange, but once cooked it became a rich color associated with szechwan and a nice thick texture.  Nwxt time I would add more spices and vegetable within the last 5 minutes of cooking.  As per one of the reviews I opted to simply cook with the sauce as opposed to cooking before and tossing with the sauce.  I deveined the shrimp - but I did a little research that mentioned this step was not imperative.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
these are really good.  I used a bag of frozen cooked shrimp and added just a bit more of all the sauce ingredients to keep the same flavor even with the water accumulated from the thawing of the shrimp.  I was glad I did this because it made some extra sauce, which was nice to put over rice.  Next time I will double (or triple the recipe so that I'll have some leftovers to take for lunch the next day.  Saying that this recipe serves 4 is that it makes about 4 half cup servings of shrimp that can be served over rice.  If you normally eat more than a half a cup of shrimp over a half a cup of rice than I'd suggest doubling the recipe.  It's a great recipe and I suggest everyone try it at least once.

text:
This turned out really nicely. Four stars instead of five for the following reasons: 1) I followed others comments on doubling the sauce ingredients and I really don't think I would want to try it with any less sauce. 2) Next time I will use raw shrimp instead of pre-cooked - as others have said, the pre-cooked shrimp did turn a little rubbery by the time the sauce had thickened. But the flavor was great and it really did only take 20 minutes, which is amazing. I would guess adding raw shrimp would only take another 5-10 minutes, at most. Great recipe, can't wait for lunch today (I have leftovers!)

text:
This is a good recipe, and seems to be even better the next day.  Here's what I did differently 1) tripled the sauce ingredients 2) Added a little extra honey because I like things a little sweeter 3) Instead of green onions I used 1 sweet onion and 1 green pepper 4) I hate when pre-cooked shrimp gets cooked again - it seems to get rubbery, so what I did was heat the sauce until it was thick and bubbly, and then added the shrimp at the very end, took off the heat and just stirred it in.

userID:

Display Name:
dianekp
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6154678.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never found a recipe which replicates authentic asian cuisine, and that is true of this recipe as well.  But that said, it was very good. I scanned through many of the reviews and used a combination of several recommendations in mine.  I think you do need to increase the sauce if you are going to serve it over rice.  I tripled the sauce recipe.  I cut back on the ketchup by 1 TBSP., the cornstarch by 1 tsp., the red pepper flakes by half, used 1 tsp. fresh minced ginger in place of ground, added a combination of about 3 cups fresh vegetables (broccoli, carrots, celery, onion), and a can of sliced water chestnuts. Use fresh vegetables and stir-fry unitl tender crisp.  You will probably need to add another Tablespoon of oil when stir-frying. The sauce complimented the vegetables and shrimp nicely.  This recipe would also be good with chicken.  We will make this recipe again.

text:
Wow. Talk about fast and simple meals. I would have given it a 5 if not for the crucial (I feel) additions. I followed the instructions of other reviewers and doubled the sauce; however, I kept the cayenne amount the same at a 1/2 tsp (I felt it was perfect, but it made the top of my dad's head sweat - my spicy meter - so I'll tone it down a bit for my parents next time and extra cayenne to my own bowl). I would suggest adding a couple of cloves (or maybe 3...or 4 - I love me some garlic) of minced garlic, substituting about a 1/4 cup chopped yellow onion for the green onion, and then frying them on medium heat for a a minute or two. I would also personally recommend buying a fresh head of broccoli and cutting off the florets in 1 - 1 1/2 inch long pieces with a 1/2 - 1 inch width. Then stir frying (3-5 minutes) the broccoli with fresh matchstick carrots with the garlic and onion after their fry time is up. Continue with the recipe, after that!  I implore you to avoid using frozen vegetables that are microwaved. It detracts from the taste, nutrients, and crispness.

Hmmm....I had great expectations here but I tasted way too much tomato (rather than a Szechwan sauce).  I could taste ketchup. Maybe it was the brand I used or maybe it was the fact that I trippled the recipe (maybe the servings calculator was off).  Regardless, it's worth a try but not going in my recipe box.  Who knows.  I also used fresh ginger and it was a good addition.  Since I didn't care for the flavor, I really modified the sauce by adding 3T of peanut butter and about a tsp of sesame oil.  This improved things greatly. Give it a try, maybe you'll have more luck.

text:
Sauce = great.  I added 1.5x the shrimp, didn't change the quantity of sauce and it turned out perfectly.  Added red capsicum, white onion roughly chopped, and long beans cut into 1.5 inch pieces.  Served it with rice.  The sauce-rice ratio was perfect - not too wet, not too dry.  Forget about buying bottled sauces from now on.  I tripled the crushed red pepper.  If you've ever been to SE Asia I'm certain you can handle upping the heat in this recipe.

text:
Very good ... but not a "5". I read a dozen reviews and decided to stay with the original recipe but double the sauce in volume. Next time I will skip the honey and ketchup, substitute another tomato product (paste ?) to reduce the sweetness, and reduce the cornstarch a little. Came out thick with little left for the rice. By ALL means USE FRESH GINGER!!
1/11/2010 UPDATE: I made it again last night, as written originally. I doubled the sauce and used uncooked shrimp ..... HUGE improvement over my first experience ... must be the flavor provided by the shrimp juices. Anyway - NO REAL CHANGES REQUIRED!!!!

I probably would have given this 5 stars, had I not been such a wuss when it came to the spice! The flavors of the sauce were awesome, it was just a bit too spicy for my taste. Meaning, my mouth was on fire! I was looking for something different than your typical teriyaki stir fry, and this was the perfect solution. It was a perfect amount for myself and my hungry boyfriend, and there were leftovers for him to take for lunch today.

text:
I have now made this recipe twice and I have to say....YUM.  I would suggest doubling the sauce recipe.  The recipe really serves 2 people as a main course.  I have tried it on rice but enjoyed it more using rice noodles and they can be found in any asian food section of a grocery store.  I double the amount of red peppers to give the recipe a bit more zing.  If you find the sauce is too thick just add a little water to it.  It's a really easy recipe and so quick to prepare.

I hate when I try a recipe having high hopes for it and then I come away feeling let down.  Unfortunately it happened with this.  

I did triple the "sauce" ingredients so that we would have more (which was recommended by numerous other reviewers) which was probably it's saving grace. I also added 3 full teaspoons of crushed red pepper (we like things spicy here) which gave it a good kick.  

I'm not all that sure I'll bother making this again since the flavor was kind of boring, other than the heat from the red pepper.  Maybe with a bit of tweaking this might become a regular in dinner rotation here...we'll see.

text:
FANTASTIC!!  I made this for dinner last night served over white rice and we loved it.  I had the leftovers today for lunch.  I followed the recipe exactly but quardrupled the sauce and I'm glad I did.  I made mine with chicken cut into strips and cooked them seperatly first.  I reccommend doing this because once you add the sauce it only takes a minuet or two to thicken  wouldnt have been enough time to fully cook the chicken.  Its probably perfect for shrimp as it only takes a few minutes to cook. As far as heat I thought it was perfect of course we like spicy!!  I even added a few dashes of cayenne pepper (Oh yeah we like it HOT!)  Definately a keeper and will make this again many more times.  Next time I will add some crunchy oriental veggies  YUMMY!!!  Thanks for the post!

userID:
558025
Display Name:
ALEXSMOMI
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
66
favoritesCount:
418
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We were not nearly as impressed as others with this dish.  As did some others, we felt it was pretty bland.  I tried to "kick it up a notch" by adding some lime juice and then added some ground mustard but it still wasn't anything exciting.  I then added some onion powder and worcestershire (sp?) sauce which livened it up somewhat.  It was good - but nothing to write home about.  I wouldn't make it again.  For those who do like it, I used cooked frozen shrimp.  I thawed it in cool water and then took off the tails.  I let the sauce thicken and THEN added the shrimp, and kept it all on the burner but with the burner off.  The shrimp warmed up nicely but didn't get overcooked as I'm afraid it would if I added it and then cooked the sauce.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmmmm! Just made this for dinner tonight and it was yummy. My husband  and 5 yr. old daughter loved it too. The only change I made was that I added lots of veggies to it. 1/2 of a large onion sliced, handful of trimmed peapods, 1/2 of a red pepper, a handful of carrots (both cut into matchsticks),1 small zucchini sliced, and extra garlic. I had made 3x the sauce that it called for as I thought I would need it with all the added veggies but I only used 1/2 of it and it was plenty. I didn't want it swimming in sauce so the veggies would lose their crunch. This is definitely a keeper!!
